BC-SCIENCE-TIMES-BUDGET-NYT 
   The New York Times News Service plans the following    Science
Times    stories for papers of Tuesday, Oct. 26:

   The first two stories were also listed on the AM-NYT-BUDGET.

   SCI-ANTARCTIC-ICE (Undated) _ Radar pictures of Antarctica
released last week contain clues collected by a Canadian-American
satellite expected to help in forecasting the fate of low-lying
parts of the world, including Bangladesh, the Netherlands and New
York City. Environmentalists are keenly interested in Antarctica
because of the possibility that some of its gigantic ice cap, which
contains about 90 percent of the world's ice, could slide into the
sea. If just part of the ice cap _ the West Antarctic Ice Sheet _
should do this, global sea level would swiftly rise by about 17
feet, inundating coastal regions everywhere with catastrophic
consequences for humanity. By Malcolm W. Browne.

   With graphic.

   SCI-BRAZIL-SKULL (Rio de Janeiro) _ A human skull at the
National Museum of Brazil here has been attracting crowds and
controversy in equal measure since it was unveiled this month.
After two decades in storage, the skull has now been identified as
the oldest human remains ever recovered in the Western Hemisphere.
The skull is that of a young woman believed to have roamed the
savannah of south-central Brazil some 11,500 years ago. A
reconstruction of her cranium indicates that her features are
negroid rather than mongoloid, suggesting that the New World may
have initially been settled not only earlier than thought, but by a
people distinct from the ancestors of today's Amerindians. By Larry
Rohter. (1400 words)

   With map.

   SCI-BRAIN (Undated) _ A highly respected neuroscientist has
developed a provocative new theory of how the brain is organized
which, if confirmed, would explain how and why the mind produces
symptoms found in several seemingly unrelated disorders. According
to the theory, the deep sadness in severe depression, the hand
wringing in obsessive compulsive disorder, the ringing in the ears
of tinnitus, the unrelenting discomfort of chronic pain and the
shaking and immobility seen Parkinson's disease all stem from the
same basic brain defect _ a decoupling of two brain regions that
normally fire their cells in synchrony. By Sandra Blakeslee. (1000
words)

   With graphic.

   SCI-GAMMA-RAYS (Undated) _ Astronomers who study the huge
explosions called gamma ray bursts are discovering a universe that
is more like a wild, all-night disco party. And with a new
generation of gamma ray observatories coming into operation now,
astronomers say that the party is just beginning. By James Glanz.
(1360 words)

   SCI-BLACK-HOLES (Undated) _ A new calculation suggests that
dense star clusters, which are sprinkled throughout galaxies in
Earth's cosmic neighborhood, act as assembly lines for tightly
orbiting pairs of black holes and then spit them out of the
cluster. There, they eventually fall together and merge into one.
Next year, if all goes well, scientists will be able to take the
first steps toward testing that theory with a new $350 million
instrument called a gravity wave observatory. By James Glanz. (1200
words)

   With graphic.

   SCI-GENOME-RACE (Rockville, Md.) _ The two rival teams racing to
decode the human genome have each neared or passed important
milestones. Biologists hope a completed genetic sequence will lay
the basis for virtually all diseases to be understood, and with
luck treated, in terms of the specific genes or genetic defects
that are involved. By Nicholas Wade. (1500 words)

   With graphic.

   SCI-ARTHUR-CLARKE (Undated) _ A conversation with Arthur C.
Clarke, the science and science fiction writer best known for his
work with Stanley Kubrick on ``2001: A Space Odyssey.'' He
discusses his predictions, his thoughts on HAL and explains why he
loves the Chelsea Hotel. By Claudia Dreifus. (1360 words)

   With phone.

   SCI-WATCH (Undated) _ News and notes on science: Items on
discounting the ocean theory on Mars, silicon sponges and assessing
hurricanes. By Henry Fountain. (685 words)

   SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) _ The Personal Health column: As many
as 4,000 children and young adults died last year of long QT
syndrome, a usually unrecognized inherited defect in the heart's
rhythm. Often, the first clue that something is wrong with the way
the heart beats is sudden cardiac death. By Jane E. Brody. (1280
words)

   SCI-HOSPITAL-RISK (Undated) _ An essay. Hospitals may not be
called pest houses anymore, but they are still terrible places to
be sick. They are all crawling with bacteria, with strangers who
are sometimes kindly but sometimes not, with the potential for bad
accidents; hospitals assault the senses from every direction, and
then they send a bill. No, from time immemorial it has always been
far better, if possible, to be sick at home, surrounded by familiar
comforts and tended by a devoted relative or friend. An essay by
Abigail Zuger, M.D. (1050 words)

   SCI-OVARY (New York) _ In an experimental operation last
Thursday that one doctor called ``great work'' but another called
``preposterous,'' surgeons in Brooklyn removed a woman's ovaries,
sliced them into thin strips and implanted them into her arm. The
patient, in her 30s, had cervical cancer, and the reason for the
seemingly outlandish procedure was to protect her ovaries from
radiation treatment planned for the cancer. By Denise Grady. (1400
words)

   With photo and graphic.

   SCI-CELLPHONE-SAFETY (Washington) _ New concerns about cell
phone safety prompt more federal testing. By Warren E. Leary. (1100
words)

   SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) _ News and notes on health and
fitness:

   _ A new study suggests that chronic lack of sleep may make the
aging process that much harsher. (200 words)

   _ As many as 1 in 10 people may be at increased risk of heart
attack or stroke simply because they carry a gene that can lead to
a serious metabolic disorder, even if they are in otherwise good
health, recent studies suggest. By Eric Nagourney. (300 words)

   _ Anesthesiologists, like many doctors, tend to be wary of
herbal medicines. But now anesthesiologists have begun turning to
an herb to help treat a deadly and often intractable lung condition
that affects hundreds of thousands of people a year. The herb is
borage, valued until now mainly for its slightly cucumberish taste
and its eye-pleasing purple and pink flowers. By Eric Nagourney.
(290 words)

   _ Despite renewed efforts across the country to educate
teen-agers about sex and repercussions like pregnancy and disease,
many young people say they still need more information about the
subject. A new study of high school students suggests that they are
right. (280 words)

   _ It's not the ghosts, the witches or even all that sugar that
puts children at risk if they go out trick-or-treating. It's the
cars. More than 700 children are killed by cars each year, and
24,000 more are injured and it's four times as likely to happen on
Halloween. By Eric Nagourney. (180 words)

   SCI-Q&A (Undated) _ Science question answered: Q. You hear all
the time about people who are allergic to cats and dogs; do cats
and dogs ever develop allergies? A. Yes ... By C. Claiborne Ray.

   Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients.
Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make
individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (212) 556-4204.

   Some ScienceTimes stories are available to international clients
only by special arrangement, and are so marked. Asian and European
points: contact Karl Horwitz in Paris for details and prices
(Phone: 47 42 17 11; FAX: 47-42-80-44). Latin American points:
contact Olivia Vasquez in Los Angeles (Phone: 310-996-0075; FAX:
310-996-0089).
